nutrient-ratio-page.title: Step 2. Set Caloric Ratios

home-page.desc-1: for diabetic pregnant women for a healthy pregnancy journey.

auth-reset-form.header-desc: Enter your email for password reset.

calc-hover.light-desc: Minimal physical activity, sedentary work, pregnant women
calc-hover.common-desc: Standing work, walking less than 1 hour
calc-hover.hard-desc: Walking more than 1 hour, daily exercise
calc-hover.carbo-desc: The recommended carbohydrate intake for pregnant women aged 19-50 is at least 175g per day. The appropriate carbohydrate ratio is 45 ~ 65%, and the Korean Diabetes Association recommends around 50%.
calc-hover.protein-desc: According to the Korean Nutritional Recommendations, the daily protein requirement is increased by 15g in mid-pregnancy and 30g in late pregnancy, based on the pre-pregnancy recommendation of 50-55g per day. The appropriate protein intake ratio is 10 ~ 35%.
calc-hover.fat-desc: The appropriate fat intake ratio is 20 ~ 35%.
calc-hover.kcal-title: Daily Caloric Needs for Pregnant Women
calc-hover.kcal-desc: During pregnancy, it is important to prevent ketosis by ensuring daily caloric intake does not fall below 1,700~1,800 kcal.

calc-alert.edit-meal-title-pl: e.g. Gestational Diabetes Diet - Final ver.

PregnancyDiabetesEducation.title: Gestational Diabetes and Nutrition Management
PregnancyDiabetesEducation.description: This page helps patients with gestational diabetes understand and practice nutrition management easily.

section1.title: What is Gestational Diabetes?
section1.content: Gestational diabetes is a type of diabetes first discovered during pregnancy. It's like an unexpected guest that arrives during pregnancy!
section1.cause: Hormonal changes during pregnancy prevent insulin from working properly. It's like a key (insulin) that can't open the door (cells) well.
section1.effect: It can affect both mother and baby. That's why management is important!

section2.title: What is a Food Exchange Table?
section2.content: A food exchange table is a tool that groups foods with similar nutritional values. It's like putting similar toys in one box!

grains.name: Grains
grains.description: Rice, bread, noodles, etc. (main source of carbohydrates)

protein.name: Protein
protein.description: Meat, fish, eggs, tofu, etc. (source of protein)

vegetables.name: Vegetables
vegetables.description: Various vegetables (source of vitamins, minerals, dietary fiber)

fruits.name: Fruits
fruits.description: Various fruits (source of vitamins and minerals)

fats.name: Fats
fats.description: Oils, nuts, etc. (source of essential fatty acids)

section2.example: Example: 1 bowl of rice = 2 slices of bread = 1 bowl of noodles (all are 2 units of grains)

section3.title: The Concept of Units
section3.content: A unit represents the amount of food with similar nutritional value within each food group. In simple terms, think of it as a 'serving' of foods with similar nutritional value!

grains.name: Grains
grains.amount: 1 unit = 1/3 bowl of rice (about 70g) = 1 slice of bread

vegetables.name: Vegetables
vegetables.amount: 1 unit = 70g of raw vegetables or 70g of cooked vegetables

section4.title: Carbohydrate Calculation Method
section4.content: Carbohydrates are nutrients that directly affect blood sugar. They're like fuel for a car!

example.title: Example
example.content: 1 bowl of rice (3 units) = 69g carbs, 1 apple (2 units) = 24g carbs, 1 cup of milk (1 unit) = 12g carbs, 1 unit of vegetables = 5g carbs. Therefore, 1 bowl of rice + 1 apple + 1 cup of milk + 1 unit of vegetables = 110g carbs

section5.title: Nutrition Management for Gestational Diabetes Patients

regularMeals.title: Regular Meals
regularMeals.content: Divide your intake into 3 main meals and 2-3 snacks a day. It's like putting small amounts of fuel in your car several times a day.

properCalories.title: Proper Calorie Intake
properCalories.content: Determined by pre-pregnancy weight and activity level (usually 1,800~2,200kcal per day).

balancedNutrition.title: Balanced Nutrient Intake
balancedNutrition.content: It's important to consume various nutrients in appropriate proportions.

carbs.name: Carbohydrates
carbs.amount: 50-60% of total calories (rice, bread, fruits, etc.)

protein.name: Protein
protein.amount: 15-20% of total calories (meat, fish, eggs, tofu, etc.)

fiberIntake.title: Increased Fiber Intake
fiberIntake.content: Helps control blood sugar. Aim for 20-25g of dietary fiber per day.

mealDiary.title: Keep a meal diary
mealDiary.description: Record the food you eat, the amount, and your blood sugar levels.

slowEating.title: Eat slowly and chew thoroughly
slowEating.description: This aids digestion and helps you feel full faster.

waterIntake.title: Drink plenty of water
waterIntake.description: Aim for at least 8 glasses a day.

avoidProcessedFood.title: Avoid processed foods
avoidProcessedFood.description: Choose foods made with fresh ingredients.

exercise.title: Exercise moderately
exercise.description: Consult with your doctor and try activities like walking or swimming.

simpleSugars.name: Foods high in simple sugars
simpleSugars.description: Sugar, honey, jam, candy, etc. (These quickly raise blood sugar)

highFat.name: High-fat foods
highFat.description: Fried foods, fatty meats, etc. (These are high in calories and slow to digest)

caffeine.name: Caffeinated drinks
caffeine.description: Coffee, cola, etc. (These are not good for the fetus)

section8.title: Importance of Blood Sugar Management
section8.content: It's important to maintain normal blood sugar levels:

section9.title: Recommended Daily Units by Food Group

reminder.title: Remember
reminder.content: This information is a general guideline. It's most important to consult with your doctor or nutritionist to find a management method that suits you personally!
